          Status:<strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          WontFix
          (was: Unconfirmed)
          <br>
        
          Labels:<strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Restrict-View-SecurityTeam Needs-Feedback
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Status:</strong>
          
          WontFix
          (was: Unconfirmed)
          <br>
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Restrict-View-SecurityTeam Needs-Feedback
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        Many of the things you claim in your report are not security issues, e.g. bypassing the pop-up blocker or hoping the user doesn't notice a small window appear and disappear. Other terms are misused, e.g. site isolation (where separate renderer processes are used for different sites) and sandbox escape. Instead of trying to describe how things you're observing might possibly several different types of vulnerabilities, explain in plain language what happens, what you expect to have happen, and what the security impact is of what happened.<span class="line"><!---->Many of the things you claim in your report are not security issues, e.g. bypassing the pop-up blocker or hoping the user doesn't notice a small window appear and disappear. Other terms are misused, e.g. site isolation (where separate renderer processes are used for different sites) and sandbox escape. Instead of trying to describe how things you're observing might possibly several different types of vulnerabilities, explain in plain language what happens, what you expect to have happen, and what the security impact is of what happened.<!----></span><br><br>I was only partially able to examine the provided proof of concept. The chrome.py script didn't work, returning an error "jinja2.exceptions.TemplateNotFound: spoofed_facebook.html". I used "python3 -m http.server" to serve the provided poc html files. In the future, please provide all files needed for running the proof of concept, and if testing cross-origin features, include a poc that can be run on each server instead of depending on an external server.<span class="line"><!---->I was only partially able to examine the provided proof of concept. The chrome.py script didn't work, returning an error "jinja2.exceptions.TemplateNotFound: spoofed_facebook.html". I used "python3 -m http.server" to serve the provided poc html files. In the future, please provide all files needed for running the proof of concept, and if testing cross-origin features, include a poc that can be run on each server instead of depending on an external server.<!----></span><br><br>From looking at the poc, I see that it (attempts to) send its own site's cookies to another origin via a POST request. There is no Chrome security issue with doing that, so long as the origin receiving the POST request first sent the appropriate CORS preflight headers.<span class="line"><!---->From looking at the poc, I see that it (attempts to) send its own site's cookies to another origin via a POST request. There is no Chrome security issue with doing that, so long as the origin receiving the POST request first sent the appropriate CORS preflight headers.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

        try using xampp to server the second PoC (flask for some reason causes errors to js code) and use this code as a flask code (I sent the wrong one, my apologies):<span class="line"><!---->try using xampp to server the second PoC (flask for some reason causes errors to js code) and use this code as a flask code (I sent the wrong one, my apologies):<!----></span><br><br><br><br><br>from flask import Flask<span class="line"><!---->from flask import Flask<!----></span><br><br>app = Flask(__name__)<span class="line"><!---->app = Flask(__name__)<!----></span><br><br><br>@app.after_request<span class="line"><!---->@app.after_request<!----></span><br>def add_cors_headers(response):<span class="line"><!---->def add_cors_headers(response):<!----></span><br>    # Replace '*' with the specific origin(s) you want to allow<span class="line"><!---->    # Replace '*' with the specific origin(s) you want to allow<!----></span><br>    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Origin'] = '*'<span class="line"><!---->    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Origin'] = '*'<!----></span><br>    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Headers'] = 'Content-Type, Authorization'<span class="line"><!---->    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Headers'] = 'Content-Type, Authorization'<!----></span><br>    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Methods'] = 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS'<span class="line"><!---->    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Methods'] = 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS'<!----></span><br>    return response<span class="line"><!---->    return response<!----></span><br><br><br>if __name__ == '__main__':<span class="line"><!---->if __name__ == '__main__':<!----></span><br>    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)<span class="line"><!---->    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)<!----></span><br><br><br><br><br>now let me describe what i've noticed when the scenario is on display and explain:<span class="line"><!---->now let me describe what i've noticed when the scenario is on display and explain:<!----></span><br><br><br>1- when the user scrolls , a js code is triggered that opens a new window<span class="line"><!---->1- when the user scrolls , a js code is triggered that opens a new window<!----></span><br>2- a notification pops up says that the pop-up was blocked while in fact it was not, that was unexpected behaviour (that's why i saw it a bypass because this could not be achived in firefox and other browsers)<span class="line"><!---->2- a notification pops up says that the pop-up was blocked while in fact it was not, that was unexpected behaviour (that's why i saw it a bypass because this could not be achived in firefox and other browsers)<!----></span><br>3- after the pop-up has happened, this error comes along: in the browser's console:<span class="line"><!---->3- after the pop-up has happened, this error comes along: in the browser's console:<!----></span><br><br>Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'document')<span class="line"><!---->Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'document')<!----></span><br>    at HTMLDocument.create_folder (PoC.html:60:17)<span class="line"><!---->    at HTMLDocument.create_folder (PoC.html:60:17)<!----></span><br><br>saying the object "newWindow" is null, yet it still can be accessed in the program here:<span class="line"><!---->saying the object "newWindow" is null, yet it still can be accessed in the program here:<!----></span><br><br>"newWindow.document.body.appendChild(form);"<span class="line"><!---->"newWindow.document.body.appendChild(form);"<!----></span><br><br>and here:<span class="line"><!---->and here:<!----></span><br>"newWindow.close();"<span class="line"><!---->"newWindow.close();"<!----></span><br><br>what i was expecting is that i can't use the object since it's freed, yet the program continued running despite that unexpectedly and that's where i figured out that this must be a memory corruption "use-after-free" since it says it's null yet the new window was created and manipulated. therefor, this behaviour was not expected. i was trying to understand more about this behaviour, and according to a search i have found that this is can be considered a sandbox escape since it escaped the confinements and limitations forced by the browser and controlled its behaviour to execute malicious actions in behalf of the user that is not allowed to d. the following is just en example of how an attacker can take advantage of that in real life scenario to steal user's cookies by triggering an xss / takeover user's account by exploiting csrf .... it depends on the vulnerabilities in the targeted platform , putting the user's data in danger. <span class="line"><!---->what i was expecting is that i can't use the object since it's freed, yet the program continued running despite that unexpectedly and that's where i figured out that this must be a memory corruption "use-after-free" since it says it's null yet the new window was created and manipulated. therefor, this behaviour was not expected. i was trying to understand more about this behaviour, and according to a search i have found that this is can be considered a sandbox escape since it escaped the confinements and limitations forced by the browser and controlled its behaviour to execute malicious actions in behalf of the user that is not allowed to d. the following is just en example of how an attacker can take advantage of that in real life scenario to steal user's cookies by triggering an xss / takeover user's account by exploiting csrf .... it depends on the vulnerabilities in the targeted platform , putting the user's data in danger. <!----></span><br><br>4- in the new window, the js from the previous one appends a form to it and submit it to a different domain from that window (check the screenshots where the referer header is present when it's sent from the parent window <span class="line"><!---->4- in the new window, the js from the previous one appends a form to it and submit it to a different domain from that window (check the screenshots where the referer header is present when it's sent from the parent window <!----></span>http://localhost<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost"><!---->http://localhost<!----></a> in my case, and it is absent when the PoC send it through the new window indicating that indeed the code in the parent window performed unauthorized actions on the new one without user's concent or knowledge).<span class="line"><!----> in my case, and it is absent when the PoC send it through the new window indicating that indeed the code in the parent window performed unauthorized actions on the new one without user's concent or knowledge).<!----></span><br>5- the submission of the form (simulating user's clicking on submit button, not using CORS, i don't know if i explained it right) that might exploit xss or csrf on a targeted website won't need CORS since it submit it directly resulting in xss execution on a different domain if the website is vulnerable for example. in the example in the PoC, the cookies received actually belongs to the user's session on that site, not the localhost or other domain.<span class="line"><!---->5- the submission of the form (simulating user's clicking on submit button, not using CORS, i don't know if i explained it right) that might exploit xss or csrf on a targeted website won't need CORS since it submit it directly resulting in xss execution on a different domain if the website is vulnerable for example. in the example in the PoC, the cookies received actually belongs to the user's session on that site, not the localhost or other domain.<!----></span><br>6- again despite the above's error, the js code in the parent window still control the new window and closes it.<span class="line"><!---->6- again despite the above's error, the js code in the parent window still control the new window and closes it.<!----></span><br><br><br>these are my findings i hope i've provided more details about this . if you need more, i can try go further.<span class="line"><!---->these are my findings i hope i've provided more details about this . if you need more, i can try go further.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I misspoke about CORS - that is only needed if the site making the request wants to look at the response. Since your PoC doesn't look at the bytes of the response to the POST request, CORS doesn't matter.<span class="line"><!---->I misspoke about CORS - that is only needed if the site making the request wants to look at the response. Since your PoC doesn't look at the bytes of the response to the POST request, CORS doesn't matter.<!----></span><br><br>It is expected that one site (e.g. a.example) can make requests to other origins (e.g. b.example). The request to b.example will contain the cookies for b.example, and this is not a security issue as they aren't exposed to a.example, only to b.example. You are correct that this could trigger a CSRF vulnerability in b.example, but that would be a security issue in b.example, not in the web browser.<span class="line"><!---->It is expected that one site (e.g. a.example) can make requests to other origins (e.g. b.example). The request to b.example will contain the cookies for b.example, and this is not a security issue as they aren't exposed to a.example, only to b.example. You are correct that this could trigger a CSRF vulnerability in b.example, but that would be a security issue in b.example, not in the web browser.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        </div>

        for LitElement.

        <slot></slot>
      </label>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement.

    <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }

  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      <style>
        
  :host {
    --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
    --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
    --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
    color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /** Converts a <button> to look like an <a> tag. */
  .linkify {
    display: inline;
    padding: 0;
    margin: 0;
    border: 0;
    background: 0;
    cursor: pointer;
  }
  h1, h2, h3, h4 {
    background: none;
  }
  a, chops-button, a.button, .button, .linkify {
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    text-decoration: none;
    font-weight: var(--chops-link-font-weight);
    font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
  }
  a:hover, .linkify:hover {
    text-decoration: underline;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    /* Links that look like buttons. */
    display: inline-flex;
    align-items: center;
    justify-content: center;
    text-decoration: none;
    transition: filter 0.3s ease-in-out, box-shadow 0.3s ease-in-out;
  }
  a.button:hover, .button:hover {
    filter: brightness(95%);
  }
  chops-button, a.button, .button {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
    background: var(--chops-white);
    border-radius: 6px;
    --chops-button-padding: 0.25em 8px;
    margin: 0;
    margin-left: auto;
  }
  a.button, .button {
    padding: var(--chops-button-padding);
  }
  chops-button i.material-icons, a.button i.material-icons, .button i.material-icons {
    display: block;
    margin-right: 4px;
  }
  chops-button.emphasized, a.button.emphasized, .button.emphasized {
    background: var(--chops-primary-button-bg);
    color: var(--chops-primary-button-color);
    text-shadow: 1px 1px 3px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.25);
  }
  textarea, select, input {
    box-sizing: border-box;
    font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
  }
  /* Note: decoupling heading levels from styles is useful for
  * accessibility because styles will not always line up with semantically
  * appropriate heading levels.
  */
  .medium-heading {
    font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
    font-weight: normal;
    line-height: 1;
    padding: 0.25em 0;
    color: var(--chops-link-color);
    margin: 0;
    margin-top: 0.25em;
    border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
  }
  .medium-heading chops-button {
    line-height: 1.6;
  }
  .input-grid {
    padding: 0.5em 0;
    display: grid;
    max-width: 100%;
    grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
    grid-template-columns: minmax(120px, max-content) 1fr;
    align-items: flex-start;
  }
  .input-grid label {
    font-weight: bold;
    text-align: right;
    word-wrap: break-word;
  }
  @media (max-width: 600px) {
    .input-grid label {
      margin-top: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      text-align: left;
    }
    .input-grid {
      grid-gap: var(--mr-input-grid-gap);
      grid-template-columns: 100%;
    }
  }

        mr-app {
          display: block;
          padding-top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-top: -1px; /* Prevent a double border from showing up. */

          /* From shared-styles.js. */
          --mr-edit-field-padding: 0.125em 4px;
          --mr-edit-field-width: 90%;
          --mr-input-grid-gap: 6px;
          font-family: var(--chops-font-family);
          color: var(--chops-primary-font-color);
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
        }
        main {
          border-top: var(--chops-normal-border);
        }
        .snackbar-container {
          position: fixed;
          bottom: 1em;
          left: 1em;
          display: flex;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: flex-start;
          z-index: 1000;
        }
        /** Unfix <chops-snackbar> to allow stacking. */
        chops-snackbar {
          position: static;
          margin-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .project-alert {
          background: var(--chops-orange-50);
          color: var(--chops-field-error-color);
          display: block;
          font-weight: bold;
          text-align: center;
        }
      </style>

          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.

          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.

            </div>
          <!---->
            <div class="keyboard-help-section">
              <span></span><span class="help-title"><!---->Issue details<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->k<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->j<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->prev/next issue in list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->u<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->up to issue list<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->r<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->reply to current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->Ctrl+Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator"> / </span>
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->⌘+Enter<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->save issue reply (submit issue on issue filing page)<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
          <!---->
            <div class="keyboard-help-section">
              <span></span><span class="help-title"><!---->Anywhere<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->/<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->focus on the issue search field<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->c<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->compose a new issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->s<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->star the current issue<!----></span>
              <!---->
                <span class="key-shortcut">
                  <!---->
                    <kbd><!---->?<!----></kbd>
                    <span class="key-separator" hidden=""> / </span>
                  <!---->:
                </span>
                <span class="key-tip"><!---->show this help dialog<!----></span>
              <!---->
            </div>
          <!---->
        </div>
        <p>
          Note: Only signed in users can star issues or add comments, and
          only project members can select issues for bulk edits.
        </p>
      </chops-dialog>
    <mr-keystrokes></mr-keystrokes>

        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-closed-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[codeFont] {
          --mr-toggled-font-family: Monospace;
        }
        .container-issue {
          width: 100%;
          flex-direction: column;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: flex-start;
          z-index: 200;
        }
        .container-issue-content {
          padding: 0;
          flex-grow: 1;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: nowrap;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          padding-top: 0.5em;
        }
        .container-outside {
          box-sizing: border-box;
          width: 100%;
          max-width: 100%;
          margin: auto;
          padding: 0;
          display: flex;
          align-items: stretch;
          justify-content: space-between;
          flex-direction: row;
          flex-wrap: no-wrap;
        }
        .container-no-issue {
          padding: 0.5em 16px;
          font-size: var(--chops-large-font-size);
        }
        .metadata-container {
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          background: var(--monorail-metadata-toggled-bg);
          border-right: var(--chops-normal-border);
          border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);
          width: 24em;
          min-width: 256px;
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          z-index: 100;
        }
        .issue-header-container {
          z-index: 10;
          position: sticky;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          margin-bottom: 0.25em;
          width: 100%;
        }
        mr-issue-details {
          min-width: 50%;
          max-width: 1000px;
          flex-grow: 1;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
        }
        mr-issue-metadata {
          position: sticky;
          overflow-y: auto;
          top: var(--monorail-header-height);
          height: calc(100vh - var(--monorail-header-height));
        }
        mr-launch-overview {
          border-left: var(--chops-normal-border);
          padding-left: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          padding-right: var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          flex-grow: 0;
          flex-shrink: 0;
          width: 50%;
          box-sizing: border-box;
          min-height: 100%;
        }
        @media (max-width: 1126px) {
          .container-issue-content {
            flex-direction: column;
            padding: 0 var(--mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding);
          }
          mr-issue-details, mr-launch-overview {
            width: 100%;
            padding: 0;
            border: 0;
          }
        }
        @media (max-width: 840px) {
          .container-outside {
            flex-direction: column;
          }
          .metadata-container {
            width: 100%;
            height: auto;
            border: 0;
            border-bottom: var(--chops-normal-border);

          }

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      </button>

      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

      -------------------------<b class="line"><!---->-------------------------<!----></b><br><br>VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>Please provide a brief explanation of the security issue.<b class="line"><!---->Please provide a brief explanation of the security issue.<!----></b><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 117.0.5938.63 + 116.0.5845.188 (Build officiel) (64 bits) stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 117.0.5938.63 + 116.0.5845.188 (Build officiel) (64 bits) stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: windows 10 <span class="line"><!---->Operating System: windows 10 <!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br><br><br>I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to provide a comprehensive report on a critical security vulnerability identified in the Chrome browser. This vulnerability not only breaches several layers of security but also demonstrates an advanced technique for bypassing key browser defenses, specifically Site Isolation, and escalates privileges to compromise user data. I will present an in-depth analysis of this vulnerability, emphasizing each aspect and its potential risks.<span class="line"><!---->I hope this message finds you well. I am writing to provide a comprehensive report on a critical security vulnerability identified in the Chrome browser. This vulnerability not only breaches several layers of security but also demonstrates an advanced technique for bypassing key browser defenses, specifically Site Isolation, and escalates privileges to compromise user data. I will present an in-depth analysis of this vulnerability, emphasizing each aspect and its potential risks.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario Description:<span class="line"><!---->Scenario Description:<!----></span><br><br>The following scenario outlines a sophisticated attack leveraging the Chrome browser's default security settings:<span class="line"><!---->The following scenario outlines a sophisticated attack leveraging the Chrome browser's default security settings:<!----></span><br><br>Conditions:<span class="line"><!---->Conditions:<!----></span><br><br>The browser is up to date with security set to the default secure state.<span class="line"><!---->The browser is up to date with security set to the default secure state.<!----></span><br>A pop-up blocker is activated.<span class="line"><!---->A pop-up blocker is activated.<!----></span><br><br>Attack Steps:<span class="line"><!---->Attack Steps:<!----></span><br><br>Deceptive User Interface: The attacker lures the user to a malicious website, let's call it <span class="line"><!---->Deceptive User Interface: The attacker lures the user to a malicious website, let's call it <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->example.com<!----></a>." On this site, the attacker employs a deceptive user interface strategy. When the user interacts with the site (e.g., scrolls), the website triggers a seemingly innocuous action.<span class="line"><!---->." On this site, the attacker employs a deceptive user interface strategy. When the user interacts with the site (e.g., scrolls), the website triggers a seemingly innocuous action.<!----></span><br><br>Pop-Up Blocker Bypass (didn't work on firefox): Notably, the attacker manipulates the user's interactions in a way that tricks the browser's pop-up blocker. While typical pop-up blockers allow pop-ups upon user interaction (e.g., clicking), this attack manages to bypass the blocker's rules without any explicit user consent, violating the expected security protocols.<span class="line"><!---->Pop-Up Blocker Bypass (didn't work on firefox): Notably, the attacker manipulates the user's interactions in a way that tricks the browser's pop-up blocker. While typical pop-up blockers allow pop-ups upon user interaction (e.g., clicking), this attack manages to bypass the blocker's rules without any explicit user consent, violating the expected security protocols.<!----></span><br><br>Small Hidden Window: Following the successful pop-up blocker evasion, the attacker opens a new browser window, deliberately minimized to the smallest possible dimensions. This window is positioned in the lower right corner of the user's screen, effectively hiding it from the user's view while keeping the malicious website's window on display. This small, covert window mimics a benign ad, thereby preventing user suspicion or intervention.<span class="line"><!---->Small Hidden Window: Following the successful pop-up blocker evasion, the attacker opens a new browser window, deliberately minimized to the smallest possible dimensions. This window is positioned in the lower right corner of the user's screen, effectively hiding it from the user's view while keeping the malicious website's window on display. This small, covert window mimics a benign ad, thereby preventing user suspicion or intervention.<!----></span><br><br>Site Isolation Bypass: The most critical aspect of this attack is its ability to bypass Chrome's Site Isolation feature. The attack takes place within this small window, which loads a "about:blank" page. Despite the apparent isolation, the JavaScript code executed within this window has the capability to operate within the context of the user's browsing session, extending its reach beyond what Site Isolation intends to confine. This profound breach of security boundaries is a significant threat to user safety.<span class="line"><!---->Site Isolation Bypass: The most critical aspect of this attack is its ability to bypass Chrome's Site Isolation feature. The attack takes place within this small window, which loads a "about:blank" page. Despite the apparent isolation, the JavaScript code executed within this window has the capability to operate within the context of the user's browsing session, extending its reach beyond what Site Isolation intends to confine. This profound breach of security boundaries is a significant threat to user safety.<!----></span><br><br>Privilege Escalation: Within the "about:blank" page in the hidden window, the attacker injects an HTML form. This form is then programmatically submitted to a completely different domain, <span class="line"><!---->Privilege Escalation: Within the "about:blank" page in the hidden window, the attacker injects an HTML form. This form is then programmatically submitted to a completely different domain, <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>target.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://target.com"><!---->target.com<!----></a>." By doing so, the attacker attempts to escalate privileges, as they exercise unauthorized control over a different website. This action is carried out without the user's explicit permission, presenting a clear danger to user data on <span class="line"><!---->." By doing so, the attacker attempts to escalate privileges, as they exercise unauthorized control over a different website. This action is carried out without the user's explicit permission, presenting a clear danger to user data on <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>target.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://target.com"><!---->target.com<!----></a>."<span class="line"><!---->."<!----></span><br><br>User Information Disclosure: The injected payload contains a script designed to exfiltrate the user's cookies and transmit them to an external server. While the success of this operation depends on the security settings of the browser and the defenses in place on <span class="line"><!---->User Information Disclosure: The injected payload contains a script designed to exfiltrate the user's cookies and transmit them to an external server. While the success of this operation depends on the security settings of the browser and the defenses in place on <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>target.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://target.com"><!---->target.com<!----></a>," it signifies an audacious and unauthorized attempt to access sensitive user information.<span class="line"><!---->," it signifies an audacious and unauthorized attempt to access sensitive user information.<!----></span><br><br>Subtle Closure: To evade detection and user intervention, the attacker promptly closes the small hidden window after a mere 2 seconds. This swift closure ensures that the attack remains hidden from the user's view, a calculated move to bypass Chrome's security mechanisms.<span class="line"><!---->Subtle Closure: To evade detection and user intervention, the attacker promptly closes the small hidden window after a mere 2 seconds. This swift closure ensures that the attack remains hidden from the user's view, a calculated move to bypass Chrome's security mechanisms.<!----></span><br><br>In light of this detailed analysis, it is evident that this security vulnerability constitutes a grave threat to user privacy and data security. The attacker successfully manipulates both the browser's user interface and core security features to launch a covert attack with the potential for catastrophic consequences.<span class="line"><!---->In light of this detailed analysis, it is evident that this security vulnerability constitutes a grave threat to user privacy and data security. The attacker successfully manipulates both the browser's user interface and core security features to launch a covert attack with the potential for catastrophic consequences.<!----></span><br><br>Proof of Concept (PoC):<span class="line"><!---->Proof of Concept (PoC):<!----></span><br><br>To substantiate this report, I have included a Proof of Concept (PoC) HTML script that replicates the described scenario. The script can be found in the attachment. Additionally, I have provided a Flask server application to collect and showcase the user's cookies, serving as a demonstration of the potential user data disclosure along with a video recording of the scenario playing.<span class="line"><!---->To substantiate this report, I have included a Proof of Concept (PoC) HTML script that replicates the described scenario. The script can be found in the attachment. Additionally, I have provided a Flask server application to collect and showcase the user's cookies, serving as a demonstration of the potential user data disclosure along with a video recording of the scenario playing.<!----></span><br><br>Vulnerabilities Found:<span class="line"><!---->Vulnerabilities Found:<!----></span><br><br>Based on the scenario and the accompanying PoC, the following vulnerabilities are identified:<span class="line"><!---->Based on the scenario and the accompanying PoC, the following vulnerabilities are identified:<!----></span><br><br>Universal Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): The attack leverages deceptive user interface tactics to execute arbitrary scripts within the context of the user's browser, compromising the security of the browsing session.<span class="line"><!---->Universal Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): The attack leverages deceptive user interface tactics to execute arbitrary scripts within the context of the user's browser, compromising the security of the browsing session.<!----></span><br><br>Site Isolation Bypass: Despite Site Isolation being active, the attacker's code operates within the user's browsing context, defying the intended security boundary.<span class="line"><!---->Site Isolation Bypass: Despite Site Isolation being active, the attacker's code operates within the user's browsing context, defying the intended security boundary.<!----></span><br><br>Exploitation Mitigation Bypass: The attacker closes the hidden window swiftly to evade detection, making it challenging for the user to react or notice the attack, effectively bypassing Chrome's security mechanisms.<span class="line"><!---->Exploitation Mitigation Bypass: The attacker closes the hidden window swiftly to evade detection, making it challenging for the user to react or notice the attack, effectively bypassing Chrome's security mechanisms.<!----></span><br><br>Web Platform Privilege Escalation: The attack injects an HTML form and submits it to a different domain, <span class="line"><!---->Web Platform Privilege Escalation: The attack injects an HTML form and submits it to a different domain, <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>target.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://target.com"><!---->target.com<!----></a>," without explicit user consent, escalating privileges and potentially compromising user data on the target site.<span class="line"><!---->," without explicit user consent, escalating privileges and potentially compromising user data on the target site.<!----></span><br><br>User Information Disclosure: The injected payload attempts to extract user cookies and transmit them to an external server, risking the unauthorized access and exposure of sensitive user information.<span class="line"><!---->User Information Disclosure: The injected payload attempts to extract user cookies and transmit them to an external server, risking the unauthorized access and exposure of sensitive user information.<!----></span><br><br>Security UI Spoofing: The attacker skillfully creates a deceptive user interface, making the covert attack appear as an innocent ad, lulling the user into a false sense of security.<span class="line"><!---->Security UI Spoofing: The attacker skillfully creates a deceptive user interface, making the covert attack appear as an innocent ad, lulling the user into a false sense of security.<!----></span><br><br>I urge the Chrome security team to prioritize the investigation of these critical security flaws. They present numerous vulnerabilities that can compromise user data, and their ability to bypass Site Isolation is especially concerning.<span class="line"><!---->I urge the Chrome security team to prioritize the investigation of these critical security flaws. They present numerous vulnerabilities that can compromise user data, and their ability to bypass Site Isolation is especially concerning.<!----></span><br><br><br>Sincerely,<span class="line"><!---->Sincerely,<!----></span><br><br>Ala Bouali.<span class="line"><!---->Ala Bouali.<!----></span><br><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Ala Bouali from Sfax, Tunisia<span class="line"><!---->Ala Bouali from Sfax, Tunisia<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Hello, I would like to submit a better version of the PoC which really highlight important thing: when the new window created, an alert to the user that the pop-up was blocked but as you can see in the recording and when you try it by yourselves , it was not blocked ! So this will increase the false sense of security for the user and won't pay much attention to the small window spawned in the lower right corner of the screen !<span class="line"><!---->Hello, I would like to submit a better version of the PoC which really highlight important thing: when the new window created, an alert to the user that the pop-up was blocked but as you can see in the recording and when you try it by yourselves , it was not blocked ! So this will increase the false sense of security for the user and won't pay much attention to the small window spawned in the lower right corner of the screen !<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I would like to add 2 other vulnerabilities: sandbox escape and memory corruption based on the errors in the screenshot and behaviour of the code despite that:<span class="line"><!---->I would like to add 2 other vulnerabilities: sandbox escape and memory corruption based on the errors in the screenshot and behaviour of the code despite that:<!----></span><br><br>Description:<span class="line"><!---->Description:<!----></span><br>In the context of the provided scenario and considering it's running on the Chrome browser, a unique and potentially serious issue has emerged, exhibiting characteristics of both a sandbox escape vulnerability and memory corruption, specifically aligning with the "Use-After-Free" memory corruption category.<span class="line"><!---->In the context of the provided scenario and considering it's running on the Chrome browser, a unique and potentially serious issue has emerged, exhibiting characteristics of both a sandbox escape vulnerability and memory corruption, specifically aligning with the "Use-After-Free" memory corruption category.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario:<span class="line"><!---->Scenario:<!----></span><br><br>The scenario initiates the creation of a new browser window programmatically.<span class="line"><!---->The scenario initiates the creation of a new browser window programmatically.<!----></span><br>A form is dynamically generated and injected into this newly created window.<span class="line"><!---->A form is dynamically generated and injected into this newly created window.<!----></span><br>Subsequently, this form is programmatically submitted within the new window's context.<span class="line"><!---->Subsequently, this form is programmatically submitted within the new window's context.<!----></span><br>Despite the presence of an active pop-up blocker, the JavaScript code continues to execute, leading to an intriguing series of events.<span class="line"><!---->Despite the presence of an active pop-up blocker, the JavaScript code continues to execute, leading to an intriguing series of events.<!----></span><br><br><br>Error Message:<span class="line"><!---->Error Message:<!----></span><br><br>Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'document')<span class="line"><!---->Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'document')<!----></span><br>at HTMLDocument.create_folder (PoC.html:60:17)<span class="line"><!---->at HTMLDocument.create_folder (PoC.html:60:17)<!----></span><br><br><br>Explanation:<span class="line"><!---->Explanation:<!----></span><br><br>Sandbox Escape:<span class="line"><!---->Sandbox Escape:<!----></span><br>This vulnerability exhibits characteristics of a sandbox escape. A sandbox is a security mechanism that restricts the actions of web content within a confined environment to prevent malicious activities. However, in this scenario, despite the presence of a pop-up blocker, the code manages to manipulate browser behavior beyond the sandbox's constraints.<span class="line"><!---->This vulnerability exhibits characteristics of a sandbox escape. A sandbox is a security mechanism that restricts the actions of web content within a confined environment to prevent malicious activities. However, in this scenario, despite the presence of a pop-up blocker, the code manages to manipulate browser behavior beyond the sandbox's constraints.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario-Based Explanation: The JavaScript code successfully creates a new browser window and interacts with it programmatically, bypassing the pop-up blocker. This implies a potential escape from the constraints imposed by the browser's sandbox.<span class="line"><!---->Scenario-Based Explanation: The JavaScript code successfully creates a new browser window and interacts with it programmatically, bypassing the pop-up blocker. This implies a potential escape from the constraints imposed by the browser's sandbox.<!----></span><br><br>Memory Corruption (Use-After-Free):<span class="line"><!---->Memory Corruption (Use-After-Free):<!----></span><br><br>The error message, "Cannot read properties of null," strongly suggests memory corruption, specifically falling under the "Use-After-Free" category.<span class="line"><!---->The error message, "Cannot read properties of null," strongly suggests memory corruption, specifically falling under the "Use-After-Free" category.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario-Based Explanation: The error implies that the newWindow object, representing the newly opened browser window, may have been prematurely deallocated or corrupted in memory. Despite this apparent memory error, the code execution persists, indicating a use-after-free memory corruption issue.<span class="line"><!---->Scenario-Based Explanation: The error implies that the newWindow object, representing the newly opened browser window, may have been prematurely deallocated or corrupted in memory. Despite this apparent memory error, the code execution persists, indicating a use-after-free memory corruption issue.<!----></span><br><br>Categorization:<span class="line"><!---->Categorization:<!----></span><br><br>Memory Corruption (Use-After-Free): Based on the scenario, the error message, and the context of running on the Chrome browser, this vulnerability aligns with the "Use-After-Free" memory corruption category.<span class="line"><!---->Memory Corruption (Use-After-Free): Based on the scenario, the error message, and the context of running on the Chrome browser, this vulnerability aligns with the "Use-After-Free" memory corruption category.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Many of the things you claim in your report are not security issues, e.g. bypassing the pop-up blocker or hoping the user doesn't notice a small window appear and disappear. Other terms are misused, e.g. site isolation (where separate renderer processes are used for different sites) and sandbox escape. Instead of trying to describe how things you're observing might possibly several different types of vulnerabilities, explain in plain language what happens, what you expect to have happen, and what the security impact is of what happened.<span class="line"><!---->Many of the things you claim in your report are not security issues, e.g. bypassing the pop-up blocker or hoping the user doesn't notice a small window appear and disappear. Other terms are misused, e.g. site isolation (where separate renderer processes are used for different sites) and sandbox escape. Instead of trying to describe how things you're observing might possibly several different types of vulnerabilities, explain in plain language what happens, what you expect to have happen, and what the security impact is of what happened.<!----></span><br><br>I was only partially able to examine the provided proof of concept. The chrome.py script didn't work, returning an error "jinja2.exceptions.TemplateNotFound: spoofed_facebook.html". I used "python3 -m http.server" to serve the provided poc html files. In the future, please provide all files needed for running the proof of concept, and if testing cross-origin features, include a poc that can be run on each server instead of depending on an external server.<span class="line"><!---->I was only partially able to examine the provided proof of concept. The chrome.py script didn't work, returning an error "jinja2.exceptions.TemplateNotFound: spoofed_facebook.html". I used "python3 -m http.server" to serve the provided poc html files. In the future, please provide all files needed for running the proof of concept, and if testing cross-origin features, include a poc that can be run on each server instead of depending on an external server.<!----></span><br><br>From looking at the poc, I see that it (attempts to) send its own site's cookies to another origin via a POST request. There is no Chrome security issue with doing that, so long as the origin receiving the POST request first sent the appropriate CORS preflight headers.<span class="line"><!---->From looking at the poc, I see that it (attempts to) send its own site's cookies to another origin via a POST request. There is no Chrome security issue with doing that, so long as the origin receiving the POST request first sent the appropriate CORS preflight headers.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        try using xampp to server the second PoC (flask for some reason causes errors to js code) and use this code as a flask code (I sent the wrong one, my apologies):<span class="line"><!---->try using xampp to server the second PoC (flask for some reason causes errors to js code) and use this code as a flask code (I sent the wrong one, my apologies):<!----></span><br><br><br><br><br>from flask import Flask<span class="line"><!---->from flask import Flask<!----></span><br><br>app = Flask(__name__)<span class="line"><!---->app = Flask(__name__)<!----></span><br><br><br>@app.after_request<span class="line"><!---->@app.after_request<!----></span><br>def add_cors_headers(response):<span class="line"><!---->def add_cors_headers(response):<!----></span><br>    # Replace '*' with the specific origin(s) you want to allow<span class="line"><!---->    # Replace '*' with the specific origin(s) you want to allow<!----></span><br>    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Origin'] = '*'<span class="line"><!---->    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Origin'] = '*'<!----></span><br>    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Headers'] = 'Content-Type, Authorization'<span class="line"><!---->    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Headers'] = 'Content-Type, Authorization'<!----></span><br>    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Methods'] = 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS'<span class="line"><!---->    response.headers['Access-Control-Allow-Methods'] = 'GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, OPTIONS'<!----></span><br>    return response<span class="line"><!---->    return response<!----></span><br><br><br>if __name__ == '__main__':<span class="line"><!---->if __name__ == '__main__':<!----></span><br>    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)<span class="line"><!---->    app.run(host='0.0.0.0', port=5000)<!----></span><br><br><br><br><br>now let me describe what i've noticed when the scenario is on display and explain:<span class="line"><!---->now let me describe what i've noticed when the scenario is on display and explain:<!----></span><br><br><br>1- when the user scrolls , a js code is triggered that opens a new window<span class="line"><!---->1- when the user scrolls , a js code is triggered that opens a new window<!----></span><br>2- a notification pops up says that the pop-up was blocked while in fact it was not, that was unexpected behaviour (that's why i saw it a bypass because this could not be achived in firefox and other browsers)<span class="line"><!---->2- a notification pops up says that the pop-up was blocked while in fact it was not, that was unexpected behaviour (that's why i saw it a bypass because this could not be achived in firefox and other browsers)<!----></span><br>3- after the pop-up has happened, this error comes along: in the browser's console:<span class="line"><!---->3- after the pop-up has happened, this error comes along: in the browser's console:<!----></span><br><br>Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'document')<span class="line"><!---->Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read properties of null (reading 'document')<!----></span><br>    at HTMLDocument.create_folder (PoC.html:60:17)<span class="line"><!---->    at HTMLDocument.create_folder (PoC.html:60:17)<!----></span><br><br>saying the object "newWindow" is null, yet it still can be accessed in the program here:<span class="line"><!---->saying the object "newWindow" is null, yet it still can be accessed in the program here:<!----></span><br><br>"newWindow.document.body.appendChild(form);"<span class="line"><!---->"newWindow.document.body.appendChild(form);"<!----></span><br><br>and here:<span class="line"><!---->and here:<!----></span><br>"newWindow.close();"<span class="line"><!---->"newWindow.close();"<!----></span><br><br>what i was expecting is that i can't use the object since it's freed, yet the program continued running despite that unexpectedly and that's where i figured out that this must be a memory corruption "use-after-free" since it says it's null yet the new window was created and manipulated. therefor, this behaviour was not expected. i was trying to understand more about this behaviour, and according to a search i have found that this is can be considered a sandbox escape since it escaped the confinements and limitations forced by the browser and controlled its behaviour to execute malicious actions in behalf of the user that is not allowed to d. the following is just en example of how an attacker can take advantage of that in real life scenario to steal user's cookies by triggering an xss / takeover user's account by exploiting csrf .... it depends on the vulnerabilities in the targeted platform , putting the user's data in danger. <span class="line"><!---->what i was expecting is that i can't use the object since it's freed, yet the program continued running despite that unexpectedly and that's where i figured out that this must be a memory corruption "use-after-free" since it says it's null yet the new window was created and manipulated. therefor, this behaviour was not expected. i was trying to understand more about this behaviour, and according to a search i have found that this is can be considered a sandbox escape since it escaped the confinements and limitations forced by the browser and controlled its behaviour to execute malicious actions in behalf of the user that is not allowed to d. the following is just en example of how an attacker can take advantage of that in real life scenario to steal user's cookies by triggering an xss / takeover user's account by exploiting csrf .... it depends on the vulnerabilities in the targeted platform , putting the user's data in danger. <!----></span><br><br>4- in the new window, the js from the previous one appends a form to it and submit it to a different domain from that window (check the screenshots where the referer header is present when it's sent from the parent window <span class="line"><!---->4- in the new window, the js from the previous one appends a form to it and submit it to a different domain from that window (check the screenshots where the referer header is present when it's sent from the parent window <!----></span>http://localhost<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="http://localhost"><!---->http://localhost<!----></a> in my case, and it is absent when the PoC send it through the new window indicating that indeed the code in the parent window performed unauthorized actions on the new one without user's concent or knowledge).<span class="line"><!----> in my case, and it is absent when the PoC send it through the new window indicating that indeed the code in the parent window performed unauthorized actions on the new one without user's concent or knowledge).<!----></span><br>5- the submission of the form (simulating user's clicking on submit button, not using CORS, i don't know if i explained it right) that might exploit xss or csrf on a targeted website won't need CORS since it submit it directly resulting in xss execution on a different domain if the website is vulnerable for example. in the example in the PoC, the cookies received actually belongs to the user's session on that site, not the localhost or other domain.<span class="line"><!---->5- the submission of the form (simulating user's clicking on submit button, not using CORS, i don't know if i explained it right) that might exploit xss or csrf on a targeted website won't need CORS since it submit it directly resulting in xss execution on a different domain if the website is vulnerable for example. in the example in the PoC, the cookies received actually belongs to the user's session on that site, not the localhost or other domain.<!----></span><br>6- again despite the above's error, the js code in the parent window still control the new window and closes it.<span class="line"><!---->6- again despite the above's error, the js code in the parent window still control the new window and closes it.<!----></span><br><br><br>these are my findings i hope i've provided more details about this . if you need more, i can try go further.<span class="line"><!---->these are my findings i hope i've provided more details about this . if you need more, i can try go further.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1483664#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1483664#c7">Comment 7<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Tue, Sep 19, 2023, 1:08 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

          Labels:<strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Needs-Feedback
          
          <br>
        
        
      <div class="issue-diff">
        <!---->
          <strong><!---->Labels:</strong>
          
          -Needs-Feedback
          
          <br>
        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I misspoke about CORS - that is only needed if the site making the request wants to look at the response. Since your PoC doesn't look at the bytes of the response to the POST request, CORS doesn't matter.<span class="line"><!---->I misspoke about CORS - that is only needed if the site making the request wants to look at the response. Since your PoC doesn't look at the bytes of the response to the POST request, CORS doesn't matter.<!----></span><br><br>It is expected that one site (e.g. a.example) can make requests to other origins (e.g. b.example). The request to b.example will contain the cookies for b.example, and this is not a security issue as they aren't exposed to a.example, only to b.example. You are correct that this could trigger a CSRF vulnerability in b.example, but that would be a security issue in b.example, not in the web browser.<span class="line"><!---->It is expected that one site (e.g. a.example) can make requests to other origins (e.g. b.example). The request to b.example will contain the cookies for b.example, and this is not a security issue as they aren't exposed to a.example, only to b.example. You are correct that this could trigger a CSRF vulnerability in b.example, but that would be a security issue in b.example, not in the web browser.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      
        mr-launch-overview {
          max-width: 100%;
          display: flex;
          flex-flow: column;

        }
      <style>

            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

        <div class="target-project-dialog">
          <h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          <div class="input-grid">
            <label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

          <mr-issue-page issueclosed=""><!---->
      <style>
        mr-issue-page {
          --mr-issue-page-horizontal-padding: 12px;
          --mr-toggled-font-family: inherit;
          --monorail-metadata-toggled-bg: var(--monorail-metadata-open-bg);
        }
        mr-issue-page[issueClosed] {
